description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to provide funding to develop a network to enable NGOs to make collective decisions on the basis of need alone and to respond early and fast to ‘under the radar’ emergencies.

mailing-address.narrative: 1 Saint Johns Lane, London EC1M 4AR, United Kingdom

description.narrative: Development of innovations that are relevant to the community and have impact potential.
Engaged community confidence that the innovations being developed will help the community and will meet their priority needs.

comment.narrative: In Philippines (only lab with solutions to test), 100% of innovations tested (4/4) received an average high score.
Majority of innovations achieve a modearte to high score(3+).
100% of innovations recieved a moderate to high score (3+), with 85% receiving a high score (4+). Average score of labs: 4.38
100% of innovations tested scored moderate to high (3+). Average (mean) scores: Jordan: 4.72; Bangladesh: 3.69; Kenya: 4.62

description.narrative: Cumulative number of innovation teams enrolled in programme

comment.narrative: Planned 42

description.narrative: Human centered design approaches tested and implemented across four labs, delivering preparedness approaches which are community designed and led, leading to more prepared communities
Initial logframe as agreed with DfID
Communities are identified, engaged and involved in all stages of the innovations process and outputs are assessed using community based evaluation methods

comment.narrative: Relevant communities identified and engaged in set up of labs. Baseline data on community preparedness perceptions gathered and recorded. Contextualised community feedback mechanisms established in each lab with links to decision-makers and clear accountability flows.

Achieved:
In each of the four labs, extensive community mobilisation activities were undertaken. This was done in the form of outreach work of the lab teams augmented by communications through dedicated social media pages, radio campaigns, newspaper adverts, flyers, posters and more. The following activities were also undertaken at lab level:
• Bangladesh lab undertook a baseline study in Korail slum and three other areas
• The Kenya lab carried out a stakeholder mapping exercise and a scoping study to help identify problem areas identified by the communities
• Jordan had intensive community consultations in identifying and defining the problem area for their first design sprint.
• Philippines had a two-staged process for the call for proposals allowing the communities to pre-register, with the labs then helping with the actual submission of the final proposals. The proposal process required that an idea was submitted by a team, with at least one member of the team coming from the community they are proposing to work with.
Lab hosts chosen based upon contexually-defined community engagement process

Achieved:
Lab hosts chosen through a competitive process with an expert selection panel choosing the appropriate lab host organisations based on quality (70%) and cost (30%). The Quality focused on programme approach which focused on community engagement innovations process and their capacity to deliver the process – risk, teams, MEL, experience.
Amended Milestones Agreed.
Iterations are on-going with the agreed milestones to be finalised by March 2018.
Review of Output Milestones based on evidence from programme.
The review process is underway with the drafting of the new logframe as per the agreed timelines with DFID.

description.narrative: DEPP Labs in the four countries test, pilot and support innovations through an innovation process, learning from which is created and shared with the broader network.

comment.narrative: Proposals received from suitably qualified organisations and consortia to implement the labs in four countries with an initial design proposed for community centred preparedness approaches.

Achieved:
54 applications were received in total. A competitive and transparent tendering process was undertaken, resulting in the shortlisting of 14 applications.

Lab host proposals finalised and selected for at least two countries with two further countries in the final stages of selection (to be complete within one month) and inception workshops planned in all countries to start refining the methodological approach.
Exceeded. An expert selection panel was convened, and all four lab host organisations were chosen by June 2017, with the contracting process commencing.
Amended Milestones Agreed.
Iterations are on-going with the agreed milestones to be finalised by March 2018.
Review of Output Milestones based on evidence from programme.
The review process is underway with the drafting of the new logframe as per the agreed timelines with DFID.

Community driven innovation methodologies implemented across the labs leading to at least 12 pilot projects being supported. At least 4 case studies shared on digital platform with a focus on generating evidence on the effectiveness and quality of the innovation process

This milestone was drafted before a comprehensive understanding of lab processes and outputs had been obtained. Although the final selection of pilot projects is yet to be completed, country labs have conducted activities aimed at engaging potential innovators:
• Philippines has conducted its call for pilots and received 266 applications.
• Jordan has identified 40 innovators from over 800 applicants. During the next stage of the process these individuals will go through a Bootcamp where they will pilot ideas.
• Bangladesh have opened its call for proposals for ideas / pilots / innovators.
• Kenya are in the process of finalising their call for proposals which will be launched imminently.
The digital platform was rolled out and 11 case studies have been generated and shared around the innovations process up to the end of December 2017.

description.narrative: Increased lab and humanitarian sector capacity through learning generated and mentoring.
Labs demonstrate increased capacity to support and develop innovation

baseline.value: Labs have identified their innovation process.

comment.narrative: Achieved - all four labs have identified their lab processes
Labs demonstrate practical experience guiding innovators through all stages of the process.

Bangladesh, Jordan and Philippines have experiencing at supporting innovators at every stage of their innovation process. Kenya's innovators have just entered the final incubation stage and have conducted only initial activities, fr example their initial business model.
At least 2 labs feels comfortable repeating the innovation process without support from Global lab.

Bangladesh, Philipines, and Jordan all continue to run lab activities, though the program has officially ended. In a perception survey, both Jordan and Bangladesh reported that they can run an innovation process without support for the Global lab, and Kenya and Philippines reported that they prefer to remain connected to the network.
Labs demonstrate increased understanding of how to support innovation.

Bangladesh, Philippines and Kenya have developed a more detailed plan of support for innovators. See tab 2.c. Jordan has developed a comprehesive plan of support which it has delivered for design sprint 1 and is refining and improving based on learning for design sprint 2.
Kenya is finalising its support plan based on its newly onboarded innovators. This will be worked against at end of June

description.narrative: Programme learning adds value to the humanitarian sector

comment.narrative: Baseline is not applicable
Key stakeholders have been engaged and recognise potential value of learning.

Across the programme lab teams and the central programme team have been engaging continuously with multiple stakeholders to promote the learning and research component. This includes with partners such as the Response Innovation Lab, the Global Alliance for Humanitarian Innovation, the Humanitarian Innovation Fund, the GSMA, Humanitarian Grand Challenges and others. Programme presentations have been made at conferences of the Asian Disaster Risk Reduction Network and the University of New South Wales Urban Resilience Conference, The King Salman Relief Center and the International Humanitarian Studies Association annual conference amongst others. In the Philippines, the Lab has hosted several innovation sector learning events with other innovation sector partners known as Innovator’s Xchange which took place in July and September. The programme has contributed MEAL tools to the tool kit being collated by the RIL / GAHI and has also been field testing other tools.
Perhaps more importantly, sectorial experts have been engaged to undertake deeper research and support on the programme:
* The University of Oslo / Prof K. Sandvik has been engaged to observe and advise the labs on innovation ethics and will produce a series of public reflections and an academic review of the innovation ethics in the preparedness labs.
* Researchers have been retained to produce research products focused on effectiveness of the ‘Community Centred Approach’ employed by the labs and also to study applicable business models and pathways for innovators operating in humanitarian contexts.
* A significant piece of work is underway to study approaches to safeguarding in the labs and to develop safeguarding practices which are appropriate for a humanitarian lab context – a version of which will be made available to the sector.
* Additional research products are planned on issues such as the overall lab methodology and on the impact of partnerships on innovators over the coming programme pe
Key stakeholders recognise original/progressive learning for the sector.
To be covered in external evaluator report
Too early to assess

description.narrative: Labs have learnt from the experiences of other labs.

baseline.value: 75% (3/4) of labs scored a mean more of 3+

comment.narrative: Planned: Majority of labs have learnt something from other labs (score 3+).
The benefits of being part of DEPP Innovation labs outweigh the costs.
75% of the labs reported that the benefits of being a part of the Global lab outweigh the costs, and that they had learned from the experience.
Labs demonstrate evidence of incorporating learning from other labs into their planning/activities.

All labs demonstrate evidence of learning from other labs, Global lab and ThoughtWorks, and incorporating this into their planning/activities. For evidence of this learning please request to see lab level logframe.
Labs demonstrate evidence of incorporating learning from other labs into their planning/activities.

Bangladesh, Kenya and Jordan have incorporated learning from other labs into the design of their activities. They have provide clear examples of learning and resulting modifcations to evidence this. The Philippines lab has engaged with all other labs and received learnings that have been shared by them. However although there has been engagement with the learnings and discussions, they have not yet incorporated any of the learnings or made modifications into our plans/activities since they have not yet identified appropriate opportunities. Given that their timelines and approaches vary from other labs, it has also been difficult to incorporate changes as some lessons were about things that the Philippines lab had already completed. The lessons however are being considered as the TUKLAS team looks to different ways forward or addressing identified challenges. In particular, Philippines is learning about Jordan’s approach to support innovators rather than ideas and is considering testing a similar approach in future. See tab 2.b for me details.

description.narrative: Innovations demonstrate successful scaling potential.
% of active innovations that are making meaningful (increase of at least 4 on scaling matrix tool) progress towards sustainability/ scaling.

baseline.value: All 4 Jordan teams scored (Design sprint 1) 15/60 on the scaling matrix .

comment.narrative: Jordan innovation teams for Design Sprint 1 alone have been scored against scaling matrix. Baseline cannot be set for other labs.
Bangladesh, Kenya and Philippines innovations scored against scaling matrix

Bangladesh and Jordan have scored all of their innovations against scaling matrix. Philippines have scored 31/40 (77.5%). They plan to score the remaining ideas by July at the latest. All innovations in Kenya have been assessed against scaling matrix.

description.narrative: Lab community is meaningfully engaged in the innovation process and able to influence the innovations
% of engaged community members who feel the people in their community were listened to and their views incorporated into the design of the innovation ideas.

baseline.value: All of Jordan's innovation have pivoted due to community feedback

comment.narrative: Evidence that Jordan's innovators have integrated community feedback into design of their innovations.
80% of community members score medium to high (score 3/3.5+).
88.76% of community members scored moderate to high. This figure is the average of each labs % to ensure an equal weighting.
Evidence that innovators are integrating community feedback into design of innovation

In Bangladesh, 2/12 innovations have pivoted (changed the design or stratergy of their innovation) due to community engagement. Teams are still at a very early stage in the process so these pivots have occurred quite quickly. Additionally, lab has conducted community perceptions surveys to guage extent to which innovations are relevant to communities disaster needs.
In Philippines, 4 teams out of 40 (10%) have pivoted due to community engagement. Teams are still at a very early stage in the process so these pivots have occurred quite quickly.
In Jordan, 100% of innovations in design sprint 1 have pivoted due to community feedback. Additionally, engaged community believe that their feedback has been listened to and their comments integrated into the design of the innovations. In April, 83% of surveyed community rated the incorporation of feedback as medium to high.
Kenya has only just onboarded their innovators. Therefore, their innovators have not yet had time to integrate community feedback into the design of their innovations. This will be assessed and reported against at end of June.
N/A nearly all lab activities will be complete by January 2019 due to programme wind down.
Null

description.narrative: Labs provide useful services to innovators, including facilitating external engagement (formal or informal partnerships for innovators)
Impact of lab support and services on innovations.

baseline.value: 100% of Jordan's innovators in Design Sprint 1 have had a positive experience with lab support and services

comment.narrative: Applicable only to Jordan Lab by the end of March 2018
50%+ of innovators in Jordan have had a positive experience. Milestone 1 for Kenya, Bangladesh and Philippines TBC.

100% of innovators in Bangladesh, Jordan and Kenya report a postive lab experience. In Philippines, 83% (44/53) of innovators reported a positive experience, rating the impact of lab support on innovations 4+ ( 40% stated that lab support was helpful, but more could be done. 43% regarded lab support as essential. 11% did not know yet). 4% reported a slight or strong negative experience. 2% reported no benefit nor hinderance.
Evidence that feedback has been incorporated to improve lab services
50%+ have a positive experience. Evidence that feedback has been incorporated to improve lab services.
93% of innovators reported a postive impact (4+). All labs listened to their innovators are made signficant changes to their activities and support based on their feedback.

description.narrative: % of active innovations teams who identified a need for partner/mentor, that now have lab facilitated partners/mentors?

baseline.value: Jordan has spoken to innovators in design sprint 1 about their partnership needs. 100% of innovation teams have at least 1 lab facilitated partner/mentor.

comment.narrative: Baseline assessed only for Jordan lab at the end of March 2018
75% + of active innovation teams who identified a need for a partner/mentor have at least 1 lab facilitated partner/mentor.

92.75% of active innovations who indentified a need for a partner/mentor have at least 1 lab faciliated partner/mentor. This figure is the mean score of the lab to ensure hat each lab as an equal weighting.

All labs have spoken to active innovation teams about their partner/mentor needs.
50% + of innovation teams in Jordan's design sprint 1 who identified a need for a partner/mentor have at least 1 lab facilitated partner/mentor.

Bangladesh: Lab has completed an initial bootcamp with innovators and has conducted a capacity assessment of their needs. During these processes the labs spoke to innovation teams about their partner/mentor needs, but are yet to identify specific partners. By end of May innovators will submit their research plans which will allow labs to indentify specific partners/mentors to meet their needs.
Philippines: Labs have spoken to innovation teams about their partnership needs. 20 innovators requested the lab to faciliate at least 1 specific type of partnership. To date, 5% (4) innovators have lab facilitated partners.
Kenya: Lab has spoken to call innovators about thier partnership needs and is now working to faciliate these.
Jordan: 100% of innovation teams have at least 1 lab facilitated partner/mentor.
N/A nearly all lab activities will be complete by January 2019 due to programme wind down

Conservative estimate (total number of exchanges between labs have been 1/2) to reduce the chance of duplication. Exchanges involving all labs counted as total 1 exchange per an exchange. This number is likely to higher as this data is not systematically collected by all staff.
